question: Great Carolyn, doing any better would be a sin... Morning, Dan. What's looking good today? ...hey Chuckie, how's the woman- slayer?
answer: ...still looking for the right 18 year old wife, how you doing, pal?

question: ...if I had your looks, better.
answer: ...takes years of genetics, pal, and a Yale education... and the right tailor.

question: ...not that you learned anything, Chunk. I gotta feeling we're going to make a killing today, Marv.
answer: Yeah, where's your machine gun.

question: Joke about it. I was up all night charting these stocks. You want to see this or what?
answer: Looks bearish to me, buddy. You got it all upside down. Okay, I'm giving this to you and you alone, 'cause I feel sorry for you. Take the Knicks against the Bullets, and my pick of the day -- Duke to beat the spread against Wake Forest.

question: He's lying.
answer: Okay, sir. I'll discuss this with the broker and I'll get back to you. You're welcome. If I'm closing out this account. If he doesn't pay for it tomorrow, you pay for it.

question: Mr. Lynch, I swear to you, he's lying!
answer: Fox, you're making more problems than you are sales.

question: I don't think you're being fair, sir. You assigned me this guy, and you know he's got a history...
answer: Somebody has to pay for that error. And it's not me.

question: Buddy, buddy, buddy; little trouble, huh, today.
answer: Howard the Jerk reneged on me. I've got to cover his loss to the tune of about seven grand! I'm tapped out man, American Express got a hit man looking for me.

question: Hey, things could be worse. It could've been my money. Let me help you out, rookie.
answer: Thanks Marv, I'll make it good to you. You know what my dream is? One day to be on the other end of that phone...

question: Just put me on the institutional side of the room where the real cheesecake is. You forgetting something? Buddy, buddy, when ya gonna realize it's big game hunters that bag the elephants, not retail brokers. I heard this story about Gekko... he was on the phone 30 seconds after the Challenger blew up selling NASA stocks short.
answer: Hello, Natalie -- guess who? That's right, and you know everyday I say to myself, today could be the day... So what do you say... will you marry me? Then please can you get me through to Mr. Gekko?

question: It concerns his future!
answer: Of course he's busy, and so am I. Five minutes. That's all I'm asking. I know that if he could only hear what I have to say... it would change his life.

question: Great Charlie, any better it'd be a sin. Gotta open an account to win the lottery, Dominick. Give me 15,000, you'll have a condo in Florida next Christmas.
answer: ... sure and we'll own the airline. If he makes anybody rich, let him make himself rich, so's he can pay off his school loans.

question: ... nice to see you in such a good mood Dad, what'd Mom do, give you fish for dinner? ... You're smoking too much, how many times do you gotta go to the hospital to ...
answer: ...leave me alone willya. Only thing makes me feel good anymore. Spaghetti. She makes lousy spaghetti...

question: It's called pasta now Dad, spaghetti's out of date.
answer: ... so am I. Whaddaya want, a beer? Hey Billie, bring another for the kid, he looks good, doesn't he? ... looks like you grown another inch... but you don't look so hot, getting bags under your eyes, starting to look old like me.

question: Ah, I had a tough day. Some jerk D.K'd me and I gotta cover his loss.
answer: Speak English will ya.

question: D.K. -- didn't know -- who I was when the options he bought took a bath. He reneged on me.
answer: I told you not to go into that racket. You could've been a doctor or a lawyer,

question: Coulda been a contender.
answer: you coulda stayed at Bluestar and been a supervisor in instead of going customer relations by now, 'stead of going off and bein' a salesman.

question: Look Dad, I'm not a salesman. How many times I gotta tell you I'm an account executive, and pretty soon I'm going to the investment banking side of the firm.
answer: You get on the phone and ask strangers for their money, right? You're a salesman.

question: Dad, it takes time. You gotta build a customer list. I'm doing it. I could make more money in one year as a broker than five years at the airline.
answer: I don't get it, you get a scholarship to NYU, you get 35,000 the first year, and 50 last year, where the hell is it?

question: 50 K don't get you to first base in the Big Apple, Dad, not any more. I pay 40% in taxes, I got a rent of 15,000, I got school loans, car loans, food, park my car costs me 3 bills a month, I need good suits, that's $500 a pop, shoes...
answer: So come home and live rent free, 'stead of that cockroach palace you live in. $50,000 Jesus Christ, the world is off its rocker. I made $37,000 last year and you...

question: It's Queens, Dad and a 5% mortgage and you rent the top room--I gotta live in Manhattan to be a player, Dad. There's no nobility in poverty anymore, y'know. One day you're going to be proud of me, you'll see...
answer: It's yourself you've got to be proud of, Huckleberry, how much ya need?

question: Can you spare three hundred? Pay you back next month, promise.
answer: ...Got a 100 on me, you...

question: Not in here Dad... please. Later.
answer: ... it adds up Buddy, 300 here, 200 there. Your brother never... ...well, I always said money is something you need in case you don't die tomorrow...

question: How's Mom?
answer: ...same, pain in the ass, god bless her, talks too much... gonna take her to Florida next month... west coast, near Tampa, like to get out for good, but can't afford it.

question: ...Work okay?
answer: ...this drug testing is driving my guys nuts. I got flagged for my blood pressure pills. The only good news is, we just met with the comptroller over some union stuff...'member that crash last summer? and the investigation? Well, the FAA is gonna rule it was a manufacturing flaw in the door latch mechanism. I kept telling 'em it wasn't maintenance, it was those goddamn greedy manufacturers out in Cincinnati. And I was right.

question: That's great Dad.
answer: Damn right, it gets us out from under suspension. We'll get those new routes to Pittsburgh and Boston and the equipment we need. We're gonna compete with the big boys now.

question: Hey to Bluestar, as your broker all I can advise is hold on to that stock Dad... You sure about this FAA announcement?
answer: About what?

question: The FAA announcement.
answer: Sure I'm sure. Buddy, you got that mischievous look in your eyes. You used to smile just like that when you were a baby sleeping, just like that.

question: ...all right, send him in...
answer: Hello, Natalie, you recognize the voice? I'll give you a hint, you're thinking seriously about marrying me...

question: What are you doing here?
answer: ...And you're even lovelier than I pictured. I brought a birthday present for Mr. Gekko.

question: First of all, Mr. Fox, you can't just come barging in here. And what makes you think it's his birthday?
answer: It's in the bible, see. You better go buy him a present. Please, Natalie. Let me give him the gift; Cuban cigars--Davidoff, his favorite and hard to get.

question: Stay here, I'll see what I can do. Wait outside. Five minutes...
answer: Well... life all comes down to a few moments, and this is one of 'em...

question: If I ever need surgery, get me the heart of an arb like Yurovich, it's never been used...Happy Holideals Harold...
answer: How do you do Mr. Gekko. I'm Bud Fox.

question: So you say. Nice to meet you; hope you're intelligent. Like these, how'd you get these?
answer: ...got a connection at the airport.

question: So what s on your mind kimosabe? Why am I listening to you? Got to monitor my blood pressure, so whatever you do, don't upset me.
answer: Oh no, no...

question: Within 45 seconds, a microprocessor computes your systolic and diastolic pressure. Has an LCD readout, and it's cost effective -- less than one visit to the doctor.
answer: I just want to let you know Mr. Gekko I read all about you at NYU Business, and I think you're an incredible genius and I've always dreamed of only one thing -- to do business with a man like you...

question: So what firm you with, pal?
answer: Jackson, Steinem...

question: ...going places, good junk bond department, you got the financing on that Syndicam deal.
answer: ...Yeah, and we're working on some other interesting stuff.

question: ...A cosmetics company by any chance? What are you, the 12th man on the deal team? The last to know?
answer: Can't tell you that, Mr. Gekko.

question: So whatta you got for me, sport? Why are you here?
answer: Chart break-out on this one here...uh Whitewood-Young Industries...low P.E. Explosive earnings. 30% discount from book. Great cash flow. Coupla 5% holders. Strong management.

question: ...doesn't look like it but the best trader on the street... Sue get the LBO analysis on Teldar Paper and bring it here...what else?
answer: Tarafly...Analysts don't like it. I do. The breakup value is twice the market price. The deal finances itself. Sell off two divisions, keep...

question: Not bad for a quant, but a dog with different fleas. Come on, tell me something I don't know. It's my birthday, pal, surprise me...
answer: Bluestar Airlines.

question: ...rings a bell somewhere. So what?
answer: A comer. 80 medium-body jets. 300 pilots, flies northeast, Canada, some Florida and Caribbean routes... great slots in major cities...

question: ...don't like airlines, lousy unions...
answer: There was a crash last year. They just got a favorable ruling on a lawsuit. Even the plaintiffs don't know.

question: How do you know?
answer: I know...the decision'll clear the way for new planes and route contracts. There's only a small float out there, so you should grab it. Good for a five point pop.

question: Rip their throats out and put them in your garbage compactor. Interesting. You got a card?
answer: My home number's on the back...

question: Bud Fox, I look at a hundred ideas a day. I choose one.
answer: Well, hope to hear from you, sir.

question: OK gang, looks like we're going over 5% in Teldar, start the lawyers on a tender offer and 13D, we keep going after everything in sight but don't pay over $22. They're gonna fight, they got Myers and Thromberg doing their legal, they make Nazis look like nice guys...
answer: ...thanks Natalie.

question: ...got tickets for the Knicks tonight. Go out and cruise some bimbos afterwards, whaddaya say?
answer: ...gotta read my reports.

question: Forget charts! We're not fund managers, Bud, churn 'em and burn 'em. I'm offering you the Knicks and chicks. God save you before you turn into poor Steeples over there.
answer: ...preferably Lou Mannheim...

question: Nice guy but a loser. Lost all his equity when his firm went belly up in the recession of 71. you wanna be coming in here in your late sixties still pitching? ... Whatever happened to that cute analyst at Thudder, Wicks? ... Cindy? Susan?
answer: Cindy. Having sex with her is like reading the Wall Street Journal 'cept the Journal don't talk back. 'Sides this AIDS crap is ruining romance, nobody trusts anybody anymore, gotta get a blood test in the toilet before you leave a bar together, somebody oughtta invent an AIDS dipstick, no kidding, make a fortune. I gotta get to work... Z's today. Bud Fox.

question: What's it at now? Still moving. Great! My magic tie, Dan.
answer: Good little company. I remember when we got the money for Bluestar to build those first planes, back in the fifties.

question: Sleep with me and the secrets of the West are yours.
answer: Now that's a crap company, sure you'll make money on the takeover rumor, but what's being created. Nothing. No substance behind it.

question: Old values. Buy.
answer: Buddy, buddy, some buddy; why didn't you tell me to buy Bluestar.

question: Hey Marv, he demanded confidentiality...
answer: Gimme a break. You buy Bluestar Airlines yesterday. Today they just happen to get good news and the stock goes bat shit. You must have ESP. A real Nostradamus. Jesus Christ, what are friends for?

question: All right, I owe you one Marv.
answer: That's right, next time a little birdie talks to you, talk to me too E.F. Hutton.

question: I'd love to, Mr. Lynch, thank you.
answer: Hi sport.

question: Nice to see you again Mr. Gekko.
answer: Try the steak tartare. It's off the menu but Louis'll make it for you...

question: Uh...just a Evian, thank you...
answer: See this? Can you believe it? Two inch screen...

question: ...I can't even see it...
answer: ...for my kid Rudy -- 3 years old, electronics freak, got a liquid crystal display 'stead of an electronic beam. We're going into a new age pal. So how's business today.

question: Bluestar was at 21 and an eighth when I left the office. It might spin up to 25 by the bell...
answer: Teldar's shooting up. Buy any for yourself? Bet you were on the phone two minutes after you got out of my office.

question: No sir, that would've been illegal...
answer: Sure...relax sport, no one's gonna blow a whistle. Here, is this legal?...you wanna put it in my account? Can we have the check over here for christ's sake. Cover the Bluestar buy and put a couple hundred thou in one of those bow-wow stocks you mentioned. Pick the dog with the least fleas. Use a stop loss so your downside is 50,000, and buy yourself a decent suit. You can't come in here looking like that. Go to Morty Sills, Tell 'em I sent you.

question: Mr. Gekko -- thank you for the chance. You won't regret this, you're with a winner.
answer: ...put the rest of it in a money market account for now. I want to see what you know before I invest it...and save the cheap salesman talk, it's obvious.

question: Excuse me sir.
answer: You heard me...I don't like losses sport. Nothing ruins my day more than losses... You do good, you get perks, all kinds of perks. Stay home tonight. Louis, take care of 'im. Enjoy the lunch.

question: Hello Bud, I'm Lisa, a friend of Gordon's.
answer: Lisa. Gordon? Oh, Mr. Gekko. Sure. Would you, uh, like to come in?

question: Didn't he tell you? That's so like Gordon. Get dressed, we're going out.
answer: We are? So, where are we going?

question: Wherever you like, Lutece, 21, the River Cafe...or maybe we can just drive around for a while. Work up an appetite. Want some? Gordon tells me you're a very talented broker. What do you like?
answer: Like? Uh...hmmm. Well...

question: I got this guy who should know tells me buy Hewlitt Packard but I been burned on tips. What do you think Bud?
answer: Let's see, it closed at uh, 41 1/8... Up a quarter...very attractive... about average yield... Rising profits...strong balance sheets, good earnings per share.

question: So you're hot on this stock?
answer: It's ready to take off. I'd jump all over it if I were you.

question: It's ready to take off. I'd jump all over it if I were you.
answer: Morning Buddy, you look happy.

question: Any better and I'd be guilty.
answer: You were never that innocent sugarpie.

question: ...come on sport, you gotta try harder, I need some exercise for chrissake...
answer: Mr. Gekko, I don't think I can...go on.

question: ...finish out the game, Bud, push yourself... The public is out there throwing darts at a board, sport. I don't throw darts at a board. I only bet sure things. Read Sun Tzu's "The Art of War." 'every battle is won before it is ever fought.' Think about it.
answer: Nice club, Mr. Gekko...

question: Yeah... not bad for a City College boy. Bought my way into this club and now every one of these ivy league schmucks is sucking my kneecaps...I just got on the Board of the Zoological Society, cost me a million; that's the thing with WASPS -- they like animals but they can't stand people!
answer: Uh, Mr. Gekko, we took a little loss today. We got stopped out on Tarafly... ...about 50 thousand.

question: I guess your father's not a union representative on that company.
answer: What? How do you know about my father?

question: The most valuable commodity I know of is information. Wouldn't you agree on that?
answer: Yes...

question: You're not as smart as I thought you were, Buddy boy, Listen hard -- don't count on Graham and Dodd to make you a fortune, everybody in the market knows the theory, ever wonder why fund managers can't beat the S&P 500? 'Cause they're sheep -- and the sheep get slaughtered. I been in the business since '69. Most of these high paid MBAs from Harvard never make it. You need a system, discipline, good people, no deal junkies, no toreadores, the deal flow burns most people out by 35. Give me PSHs -- poor, smart and hungry. And no feelings. You don't win 'em all, you don't love 'em all, you keep on fighting, and if you need a friend, get a dog, it's trench warfare out there sport... and in here too. I got twenty other brokers out there, analyzing Charts. I don't need another one. Talk to you sometime...
answer: I'm not just another broker Mr. Gekko. If you give me another chance, I'll prove it to you. I'll go the extra yard for you. One more chance. Please...

question: You want one more chance? Then stop sending me information and start getting me some. Get dressed, I'll show you my charts. Know the name?
answer: 'Course. Larry Wildman. One of the first raiders.

question: Sir Larry Wildman. Like all Brits he thinks he was born with a better pot to piss in... bribed an old secretary of mine to open bar mouth and stole RDL Pharmaceuticals right out from under me. Wildman the white knight.
answer: I remember that deal. You were involved?

question: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport. ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world... Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...
answer: I don't understand.

question: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...
answer: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I... It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?

question: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that? I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...
answer: What about hard work?

question: What about it? You work hard. I'll bet you stayed up all night analyzing that dog you bought. And where'd it get you?... my father worked hard too like an elephant pushing electrical supplies. And he dropped dead at 49 with a heart attack and a tax bill and the bank pissed on his grave and took the house; my mom ended up working in a dish factory... Wake up pal, if you're not inside you're outside. And I'm not talking a $200,000 a year working Wall Street stiff flying first class and being "comfortable", I'm talking rich pal, rich enough to fly in your own jet, rich enough not to waste time, 50-100 million, a player Bud -- or nothing. You had what it takes to let through my door. Next question Look out there... You really think the difference 'tween this guy and that guy is luck? Mohammed, pull over. ...when it comes to money, sport, everybody's of the same religion. Or should be... Hope you don't mind if I let you off here, I'm late for a meeting. Good bye, nice knowing you.
answer: All right, Mr. Gekko...you got me.

question: Yeah, it's a beautiful night. I love this hot stinkin' city. ... nothing else like it in the world. Seven million people living on each other's heads, kids born, millionaires dying, people praying, junkies, whores, wills, lawyers, deals, parties, sex... guys like you sport -- dreaming about the big score. You know the best thing about New York is everything you can do here. And the worst thing is everything you can't do here...
answer: Oh shit, don't tell me Mr. Wildman was on board that plane? My boss is gonna kill me. I was supposed to give him this. You know where that plane is going? ...after spending the morning at Kahn, Seidelman -- on the 14th floor, the junk bond department -- where Shane Mora works -- he had lunch at La Cirque with a group of well-dressed heavyset bean- counters... ...he later stopped off at Morgan. I'd say from all the palm-pressing and sweet smiling going on that Larry got some nice fat financing...

question: ...bright but not bright enough, Sherlock, roll the dice and play a little monopoly... what box would Sir Lawrence land on in Erie, Pennsylvania?
answer: Jesus Christ, he's buying Anacott Steel!

question: When the market opens tomorrow, buy five thousand March fifty calls. You hear me? Start buying ten thousand share blocks and take it up to fifty dollars. When it reaches fifty, you can let out a little taste to your friends. Then call this number -- 555-7617 Start buying Anacott Steel all over the board.
answer: Hey Dad!... Hi ya Charlie... Dominick...

question: Hey Dad!... Hi ya Charlie... Dominick...
answer: What brings you out here...

question: Client. Got a private jet over at Butler Aviation... Dad, you always gotta light up when you see me, it's the...
answer: Don't start, alright.

question: Alright. Why so pissed?
answer: Goddamn fare wars are murdering us. Had to lay off five guys. Nothing I could do. What is it... money?

question: Yeah, it is. In fact I'm doing great. New client. Whole new league. It's starting to happen Dad. The Big Leagues! You know what I'm saying.
answer: Sure...lots of guys at the track talk like that... but how do you know you'll have any dough next month... What's this? I gave you two hundred.

question: Dividend. I figure I owe you about five thousand in nickels and dimes...
answer: ...don't be crazy. Put it to your school loans.

question: Don't worry about the loans. I'm doing good Dad and it's gonna stay that way now... least buy yourself a new suit.
answer: What do I need a fancy suit for. I don't hobnob with the jet set. I just fix their planes.

question: ...then buy yourself a decent bowling jacket so when you take Mom out you don't look like the Roto Rooter man. Come on, for godsakes, that's what money's for. Enjoy yourself...
answer: Problem with money is you never have enough or you got too much -- and when you got it you're never happy 'cause somebody's always trying to take it away from you. Money's one giant pain in the ass y'ask me... thanks.

question: ... Dad, you should've been a CEO. How about dinner?
answer: Whatever night you like.

question: Wait... next week's booked. Let me check with my girl and get back to you on Monday.
answer: Yeah, you do that huckleberry. I'll still be here.

question: Mr. Mannheim, got a sure thing. Anacott Steel.
answer: No such thing Bud - 'cept death and taxes. Not a good company anymore, no fundamentals. What's going on Bud? Do you know something? Remember there're no short cuts son, quick buck artists come and go with every bull market but the steady players make it through the bear markets. You're part of something here, Bud. The money you make for people creates science and research jobs. Don't sell that out.

question: You're right, Mr. Mannheim, but you gotta get to the big time first, then you can be a pillar and do good things.
answer: Can't get a little bit pregnant, Bud.

question: It's a winner Mr. Mannheim, trust me -- buy.
answer: Gotcha baby, its do-able... meet you at the Wyatt Club... 3pm Dinner Thursday... Indochina. Then we'll kamikaze down to Nell's, chase a little cotton underwear--I know this 18 year old bimbo, man... you can take it to the bank...

question: Wanna play some tennis Saturday?
answer: You mean teach you how to play. Can't. Going fly fishing in Canada, big client...

question: ...you take that Anacott Steel?
answer: ...light snack, but good, thanks pal, you're sharking your way up...

question: I'll be right there, fix them a drink.
answer: ...we have 37.2 million invested. At this point, we're up 3.1 million and some change. If it goes to 75 bucks we can clean close to 12 mill.

question: You're walking between the raindrops kid. I expect Sir Larry is choking on his royal chamber pot by now.
answer: My firm needs your signature on these option agreements tonight, sir, otherwise we could take a real bath tomorrow.

question: ...Can't it wait? I'm good for it. ...Awright. Come out, get the directions from Natalie and hurry up.
answer: Bud Fox. Got some papers for Mr. Gekko to sign. Sorry, Mr. Gekko.

question: Allright. Wait here...
answer: Problems?

question: No... Bud Fox, my wife, Kate...
answer: You came from the city? Long drive, have a drink.

question: Hello again, I been holding these drinks for us for the last three weeks.
answer: Excuse me.

question: Grand Marnier. A romantic and tragic drink.
answer: Oh yes, I remember you.

question: Destiny took us apart, but I knew it would bring us back together.
answer: Aha. Poet or philosopher?

question: Stock broker. As in
answer: I'd give anything to have this in my house, even for a week.

question: ...few thousand dollars down the drain if you ask me.
answer: Oh really? Well, I guess you can kiss that career as an art appraiser goodbye, because we paid over four hundred thousand for it at the contemporary picture sale last June.

question: You could have a great beach house for that.
answer: Sure you could, in Wildwood, New Jersey. If you sold this, you could have a pretty nice penthouse on Fifth. But you wouldn't have much left over for decoration.

question: Boy, I thought Gordon was a tough businessman, but somebody's really taking him to the cleaners here.
answer: Not really. I'd say that Gordon is one of the most astute collectors around. He has a great eye and he only buys the best. Like this rug for instance, a silk Tabriz, the finest of its kind. The day after he bought it in London, a dealer representing the Saudi Royal Family offered him twice what he paid. It absolutely makes the room. See how this little bit of celadon in the border is picked up in the cushions oh the sofa... although... I don't know if I would have used that tea dipped linen for the upholstery - too dingy. And it's a sacrilege having that Pre-Columbian pot in the center of the coffee table. Some dope might use it as an ashtray.

question: I gather you're a decorator.
answer: You got it, a great spender of other people's money.

question: Well, if you're that good, you could probably do wonders at my place.
answer: Where is it?

question: Upper West Side.
answer: Oh really. Home of the exposed brick wall and the houseplant.

question: Oh it's just a rental. I'm moving to the East Side soon. I've got a couple of deals brewing with Gordon. but that's just conversation... what about real things? Like dinner. The two of us. Friday. Cafe. Santo Domingo.
answer: What if I have a previous engagement?

question: Break it.
answer: I guess this must be destiny alright. My first yuppie apartment and... my first yuppie.

question: You may call me a yuppie... It's Mister Yuppie to you. So. See you Friday.
answer: You really do believe in destiny?

question: Stick around... Larry, one of my "gang" -- Bud Fox. Shall we go upstairs? Rarest pistol in the world, Larry, a .45 Luger. Only six were ever manufactured.
answer: Congratulations but rarer still is your interest in Anacott Steel.

question: The same interest as yours Larry. Money. I thought it'd be a good investment for my kid...
answer: No. This time I'm in for the long term. This is not a liquidation, Gordon. I'm going to turn it around. You're getting a free ride on my tail, mate, and with the dollars you're costing me to buy back the stock, I could modernize the plant. I'm not the only one who pays here Gordon. We're talking about lives and jobs; three and four generations of steel workers...

question: You must be wearing a mask you're laughing so hard behind it Larry. Let's cut the "sir" crap. Correct me if I'm wrong, but when you took CNX Electronics, you laid off 8,000 workers, Jessmon Fruit about 6,000, that airline...
answer: I could break you, mate, in two pieces over my knees, you know it, I know it, I could buy you six times ever, I could dump the stock just to burn your ass but I happen to want the company and I want your block of shares. I'm announcing a tender offer at 65 tomorrow, and I'm expecting your commitment.

question: But we don't want to be greedy now, so let's let him have it at $72.
answer: You're a two bit pirate and a green-mailer, Gekko, nothing more... not only would you sell your mother to make a deal, you'd send her COD...

question: My mail's the same color as yours Larry. Or it was till the Queen started calling you "sir". Now excuse me before I lose my temper...
Considering you brought my mother into it, $71.50.
answer: Done. You'll hear from my lawyers. 8 a.m. Good night.

question: He's right. I had to sell. The key to the game is your capital reserves. You don't have enough, you can't pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs.
answer: "All warfare is based on deception..." Sun Tzu says, If your enemy is superior, evade him, if angry, irritate him, if equally matched, fight... if not, split and reevaluate.

question: You're learning, sport...
answer: Yeah?...

question: Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out.
answer: Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%.

question: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line. Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment. ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.
answer: ...Gordon.

question: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?
answer: Well we're thinking of putting up a statue of you in the subway. I hear you're moving up in the world. An associate already. Not bad. How's Margie?

question: Can't complain. Got a house in Oyster Bay. Market treating you good? Still seeing that sexy French gal?
answer: Nah, she asked the wrong question.

question: What was that?
answer: "What are you thinking?"...that was it. The hours are hell, but the money's starting to tumble in. I know this guy who's got an iron- clad way to make money, I can't lose and I can't get hurt.

question: So, does "this guy" have a tip for an honest lawyer?
answer: Yeah, check out Teldar Paper, it's still not over.

question: Okay.
answer: What about you, I hear you guys are handling the Fairchild Foods merger and it may not be going through. Any surprises I haven't read about in the Wall Street Journal?

question: Come on Buddy, you wouldn't want to got me disbarred now would you?
answer: Who's listening? It's just one college buddy talking to another.

question: Yeah, right...
answer: Relax, Roger, everybody's doing it but you don't know, you don't know.

question: ...and if I did, what's in it for moi?
answer: More money than you ever dreamed, Roger. And the thing is no one gets hurt...how bout a beer?

question: Too much to do...but I'll walk you out. ...Get inside my uncle's door Buddy, all the secrets of the world are yours... the life blood of companies, but you gotta go to law school first...
answer: I need to speak to the owner about some business. Mr. Panos, I've charted the growth of new office space in the city, and I think you're in the right business at the right time. I'm impressed with your work and I could use a tax break. This is a growing business. Are you interested in some working capital and a partner?

question: Uh. Wrong office. Sorry...
answer: Got him at an auction in Kentucky.

question: How much?
answer: Close to two million. But this sucker can go all the way to Devon and the nationals.

question: ...piece of cake, Gordon...
answer: If I could have anything... this would almost do.

question: Yeah, almost...
answer: So, how did your conference go with Gordon?

question: The conference, oh yeah. Fine. We reached an agreement and decided to divide up the world between us.
answer: You have modest wants. I like that in a man.

question: And what do you want?
answer: ...a Turner, a perfect canary diaiaond... a Lear jet... world peace... the best of everything...

question: Well, why stop at that?
answer: I don't.

question: All right. Offer 950... Nah...this is it..home... Yes...no...at 37 1/2. Convert the bonds right...and check the price in Tokyo at 8:00 LA time. Thanks...
answer: ...isn't it perfect!

question: ...too perfect...let's not even eat. Let's just watch it and think about it. You know, the elevator man couldn't believe I paid $300,000 to have my walls looking like this, he's got them for free in Brooklyn.
answer: I'll bet he's got an opinion on the stock market too. This apartment is already ahead of its time. I call it the "demolished" look. They've already heard about it at House and Garden and they're coming next week to photograph it before it gets... lived in. Is that alright? I'd love to have it in my portfolio.

question: Sure... But your fee... considering you're way over budget, should be negotiable.
answer: Let's get things straight, Bud. I'm not going to take a cut. I worked hard and you can't decorate a room in New York for less than $100,000. Curtains alone...

question: I'm kidding, I'm kidding, we're still young, Darien. So what's money anyway when everybody's making it, it's all relative. After all, this is not the house in Connecticut, this is just a crash pad good for a couple of years...before we slip our two lovely kids, Yuppie and Fruppie into the Lycee Francaise.
answer: You got it all charted out don't you, like a stock projection.

question: That's right -- one with high yield, rich assets and no downside...
answer: Do you think you're ready?

question: It's not me I'm worried about...You know Darien, the only reason we haven't slept together is because we both know we will -- and not knowing when was the only surprise left. You owe me, I want you, what else is there...but you, me, the world. ...right here...make love to me...now... Stop me if I'm going too far.
answer: I'll let you know.

question: Is this real? Is this really real? Who am I?
answer: Come to bed, Bud...

question: Hey, I'm tired of playing nurse to you all the time, alright. Do your own home work! Buy me 20 June Euro Dollar CDs. Twenty March gold and sell 10 September Deutsch marks. That's right... Bud, I hate to tell you this but you're a genius! Darien...lightning has struck! The lightbulb has been invented. Edison, Da Vinci, Einstein are watching...
answer: ...are you going to trade all night again? You got to go to work in a couple of hours.

question: You think I'm gonna broker the rest of my life... I'm going to be a giant, Darien, an entrepreneur in the Italian 15th century sense of the word -- a mover, shaker. I love you, baby. Did I tell you that sometime in the last 24 hours?
answer: Get in bed. Y'ever hear of the sixty hour work week? You're turning into a yuppie Frankenstein, you love money so much.

question: Sure, why not, money's the sex of the 80's. I never had it like you when I was growing up, baby, it wasn't the upper east side.
answer: You're so naive Bud, you don't even know. Your dad took care of you. I might've been rich when I was a kid...but my father lost all his money...in the seventies, in the stock market, at the track. He was a lousy gambler...

question: ...that changes all my plans, I thought you were loaded...
answer: So did I, till I hit 19 and found I had all the royal habits and no throne. Mom got by but I had to go to work just like you. Only the skills I had were shopping and making friends. So...that's why I do what I do, what makes you tick, Buddy?

question: Tell those spineless toads we'll self-insure if they don't write it... You fire 33 vice presidents and nothing changes... You eating twinkies today, Bud, or are you schtupping some stewardess...
answer: Gordon what I want--and I never asked you for anything--is to be your co-pilot on this. I want to take this airline, turn it around, and make it work. It's gonna make us a fortune!

question: I'm talking to a stockbroker who wants to run an airline. It's gonna take me two years and 2000 headaches to turn Teldar Paper around, what do I need this dink airline for? I'm up to my ass in more nuts than a fruitcake.
answer: Gordon, I worked at Bluestar, I know my way around, I have friends there...inside.

question: What does that mean?
answer: The three unions. It's 43% of Bluestar's operating budget, the hourly cost of a flight crew is $850 an hour, that's the real hidden value G.G., if you can negotiate that out, get a crew down to $350-400 an hour a run, this airline is gonna be the hottest thing since Texas Air...

question: What makes you think you can?
answer: I can talk to these people Gordon, they trust me...and my father can be a big help in getting cuts.

question: Alright... Susan, get Buckingham on the box. I want him to look at it. And tell Jock Taylor at Thwick, Jensen... So sport, the falcon has heard the falconer...tell me more...
answer: Dad, well come on in. Everybody's here. We couldn't start the show without you.

question: I guess if a man lives long enough, he gets to see everything. And I mean everything. What else do you have in your bag of tricks, Mr. Gekko?
answer: Frankly, Carl, I can't see giving much more. If you have any suggestions I'll be glad to listen.

question: There came into Egypt a Pharoah who did not know.
answer: I beg your pardon. Is that a proverb?

question: ...that "scum" built this company up from one plane in thirty years, they made something out of nothing, and if that's a scum I'll take one over a rat any day...
answer: Congratulations. You did a great job of embarrassing me in there-- not to mention yourself! Save the "workers of the world unite" speech for next time Dad, I heard it too much growing up. You're gonna get axed Dad, no two ways about it, you and the whole airline are going down the tubes, you hear me, just like Braniff, you don't have a chance in hell, and if it isn't Gekko it's gonna be some other killer.

question: He's got your prick in his back pocket, son, and you're standing naked in the display window of Macy's. He's using you. Only you're too blind to see it.
answer: No, what I see is a jealous old machinist who can't stand that his son's become more successful than himself.

question: What you see, son, is a man who never measured success by the size of a man's wallet.
answer: That's because you never had the guts to go out into the world and stake your claim.

question: Boy, if that's what you think, I must've really screwed up my job as a father. ...as far as being axed, I'm still here and as long as I am, I have a responsibility not just to me but to the union members I represent...
answer: Your responsibility, Dad, is to present the facts, not your opinions, to the men... you're gonna destroy their lives, Dad! Don't do it to 'em. Give it a chance. Let the membership decide for themselves, Dad. Please.

question: I'll be damned that when my men come to me tomorrow morning, wanting to know what's going on, I'm going to lie to them!
answer: Your men! All my life "your men" have been able to count on you? Why is it that you've never been there for me? And what if you're wrong? What if one day, the sun didn't rise in the East and birds didn't fly South in winter and for once in your life your compass was off? Huh? Would you be willing to wreck your men's future? My future? Please... Dad. Think. Be practical, for a change. I'm asking you, I'm fucking begging you...

question: What's up Dixon? Calm down! What are you talking about?
answer: ...this guy who said he was from the Security Exchange Commission, whatever the hell that is, calls and wants to ask me about that stock I bought...

question: What'd you tell him?
answer: I told him I was in the bathroom and I'd call him right back. What the hell was I supposed to say Buddy, you got me into...

question: Look Dixon, calm down! It's not illegal to buy stock or to be right. And it's not all that unusual to be spot checked on a big buy. Tell him you did your homework and you thought the stock was a sound investment.
answer: What if he asks where I got the money?

question: Tell 'em your father gave it to you.
answer: What if they call him?

question: They won't. That's not their jurisdiction.
answer: You sure?

question: Yes! Read the Constitution, it's all in there. And remember--you don't know anything, nothing.
answer: I don't know anything!

question: Good. Then call him back. And call me back. Don't worry.
answer: Hey you hear the news. I just got a job at a new firm

question: Didn't I tell you to knock before you came in here?
answer: Hey the door was open.

question: Then get out and close it behind you.
answer: You know what you need, buddy buddy--an optorectomy. That's when they cut the nerve that runs from your brain to your rectum--to change that shitty attitude of yours.

question: Get the hell out! So what's the problem?
answer: ...got a strange call from the SEC. They asked to see my records... Bud, this is a heavy...

question: ....Relax Roget You're 82M in the account numbers and I'm the Invisible Man... they're always looking for red flags, Gekko's always getting checked by them, they never come up with anything... we're invulnerable on this...
answer: Alright... I just wanna slow down Bud... no more calls for awhile, no lunches... we suspend our business, alright...

question: Sure Roger, whatever you want, it's cool.
answer: Gekko asked us into the Bluestar deal. We're reviewing the timetables, wanna come?

question: He never told me...
answer: You're just the President of the company, what do you know? ... Come on. You guys know the new chief of Bluestar... Bud Fox. This is the pricetag on the 737s, the gates, the hangars, the routes, we got it all nailed right down to the typewriters...

question: I didn't know we had a meeting schedule for this morning.
answer: I'm sorry, this can't wait.

question: Will you gentlemen excuse us for a few minutes? What the hell do you want?
answer: I found out about the garage sale down at Bluestar. Why?

question: Last night I read Rudy the story of Winnie the Pooh and the Honey pot. Know what happened
answer: Maybe you ought to read him Pinocchio. You told me you were going to turn Bluestar around. Not upside down. You used me.

question: You're walking around blind without a cane, sport. A fool and his money are lucky to get together in the first place.
answer: Why do you need to wreck this company?

question: Because it's wreckable. I took another look and I changed my mind.
answer: If these people lose their jobs, nowhere to go. My father worked at Bluestar for twenty-four years. I gave 'em my word.

question: It's all about bucks, kid, the rest is conversation... Bud, you're still going to be president. And when the time comes, you'll parachute out a rich man. With the money you're going to make, your father won't have to work another day in his life.
answer: Tell me, Gordon--when does it all end? How many yachts can you waterski behind? How much is enough?

question: Buddy, it's not a question of enough. It's a zero sum game, sport. Somebody wins and somebody loses. Money itself isn't lost or made, it's simply transferred from one perception to another. Like magic. That painting cost $60,000 10 years ago. I could sell it today for $600,000. The illusion has become real. And the more real it becomes, the more desperately they want it. Capitalism at its finest.
answer: How much is enough Gordon?

question: The richest one percent of this country owns half the country's wealth
answer: Obviously...

question: Believe me, Buddy, I was gonna discuss this with you at the right time. Look, why don't you calm down and come to the apartment for dinner tonight. Bring Darien...
answer: ...I can't make it tonight.

question: Are you with me Buddy? I want you with me.
answer: I'm with you Gordon...

question: Bud?...What's going on?
answer: I've been played like a grand- piano--by the master, Gekko the Great...and today was the big crash. Liquidation sale. He's gonna carve Bluestar into little pieces and sell it all off...

question: I'm sorry. I was afraid something like this could happen.
answer: Talk about being bent over the sink of life and being dry humped. I handed it to him on a silver platter. I told my father and those people...

question: Buddy, it's not your fault, and it's not your decision.
answer: I'm not gonna let it happen Darien.

question: Don't cross Gordon. He'll crush you. You've worked hard to get where you are. If Gordon doesn't buy Bluestar someone else will; and who's to say they won't do the same thing.
answer: At least I wouldn't be pulling the trigger.

question: Are you mad! Why are you doing this! We're so close, the town is going to be ours. Don't throw away your future Bud!
answer: I can stay with the brokerage firm. And you're doing fine. We can survive without Gordon Gekko.

question: I'm not looking to just survive. I've been doing that all my life.
answer: What the hell's that supposed to mean?

question: That if you make an enemy of Gordon Gekko, I won't be there to stand by you.
answer: You really mean that? What'd he promise you? To take you public? I guess without Gordon's money and seal of approval, I'm not such a hot investment anymore. You're just the best money can buy, Darien...

question: You're not exactly pure Bud, you went after Gekko with the same vengeance you went after me. Look in the mirror before...
answer: I'm looking...and I sure don't like what I see.

question: Fair enough...but it's not that simple, Bud. When I was down and had nothing, it was Gordon who helped me. He got me all my clients -- you among them... and he can take it away like that. You may find out one day -- that when you've had money and lost it, it's worse than never having had it at all.
answer: That's bullshit! Step out that door, I'm changing the locks.

question: You may not believe this Bud but I really do care for you. I think we could've made a good team...but that's how it goes...
answer: Get the hell out! Save the rap, just sell it -- fast!

question: Look over there sunshine. I'm up against Richard Feigen. What do you say we go get a suite at the Carlyle? Caviar? Champagne? Celebrate, just like the old times Sunshine.
answer: Those days are over, Gordon. They were over a long time ago.

question: Can't blame me for trying. You look as beautiful as that painting I just bought. So what's the problem Sunshine? You look like Black Thursday. Bad case of puppy love?
answer: It's not puppy love, Gordon. Anyway, Buddy and I are splitting up.

question: Sorry to hear that. I thought the kid had staying power.
answer: It's over you, Gordon.

question: You told him about us?
answer: No, are you crazy? And I don't want him ever to know. Do you understand?... I want to ask you a big favor, Gordon. Please drop the Bluestar deal.

question: Now tell me, why would I want to do that?
answer: Because I don't want to see him hurt.

question: Don't worry Sunshine. Bud and I had a little talk. We came to an understanding. I want you to go back to him. Soothe him. Help keep his head straight. Okay?
answer: I can't...and I won't.

question: Come on, we both like Buddy. But this bleeding heart puppy love act is over the top... It doesn't fit.
answer: Maybe it does. Don't patronize me Gordon.

question: You and I are the same, Darien. We're smart enough not to buy into the oldest myth running
answer: You're really twisted, Gordon. You're incapable of giving to anybody because deep down inside you there's a poverty that every last dollar in the world won't fill.

question: Ooh ooh, tough talk from a scared little girl all wrapped in a pretty grown-up package. Does this mean you're ready to cut the umbilical cord and step out into the world on your own? Because, Darien, if you're through with me, you're through with everything I'm a part of.
answer: I know...but maybe, just maybe Gordon, I'm good enough so I don't need you anymore.

question: ...the stock's at 19 1/4 and it's going up. Gekko figures by breaking up Bluestar, it's worth at least $30 a share. That means he'll buy up to 23 or 24 and still think he's making money.
answer: How do you know that the stock is going to go up?

question: You really don't want to know any more than that, Mr. Wilmore. Let's just say I have some friends.
answer: Okay. What happens then?

question: Well, if that's how you feel--the hell with you too. And strong letter to follow.
answer: You don't have to agree with me, Marv; but I think I've been a bit of a schmuck lately.

question: I agree. Go thou and sin no more.
answer: I want to make it up to you. Bluestar, put all your clients in it.

question: Thanks, buddy, buddy, I'm back. Say, Buddy, those optorectomies do work wonders.
answer: Bluestar, Mr. Mannheim. Put all your clients in it.

question: I guess you're not here to open an
answer: Hello Bud.

question: Gordon.
answer: You sandbagged me on Bluestar. I guess you think you taught the teacher a lesson, that you can make the tail wag the dog, huh? Well let me cue you in You think you could've gotten this far this fast with anybody else? You think you could be out there dicking somebody like Darien? No, you'd be cold calling dentists and widows to buy twenty shares of some dog stock! I took you in! A nobody! I opened doors for you!...I showed you how the system works!... ...the value of information! How you get it! Anacott Steel, Brant Resources, Transuniversal, Fulham Oil. And this is how you pay back, you cockroach! I gave you Darien, I gave you your manhood. I gave you everything. You could've been one of the great ones Bud...I look at you and see myself...Why?

question: Another cup of coffee?
answer: No, thanks, I'm nervous enough.

question: I guess it's time to hit the road.
answer: Yeah, don't want to be late for my own funeral.

question: ...you told the truth, you gave the money back. All things considered-- in this cockamamie world--you're shooting par... ...if I was you, I'd think about that Bluestar job Wildman's offered you...
answer: Dad, I'm going to jail and you know it.

question: Maybe that's the price, Bud, maybe so. It's gonna be rough on you but maybe in some screwed up way, that's the best thing that can happen to you...stop trading for the quick buck and go produce something with your life, create, don't live off the buying and selling of others... ...got any friends gonna be there?
answer: Like who? Who really wants to know a convicted felon...I don't even like myself.
